description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9rtgk","text":"(MiSeq nano V2 chip 300 cycle), MiSeq multiplexes sequences, allowing you to DNA sequence multiple samples at once. This is particularly useful for genotyping fish with mosaic genotypes, such as F0 knockouts. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8u3ce","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a9gej","text":"@FishFloorUCL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

related_materials.name: Qubit™ 1X dsDNA High Sensitivity (HS) Assay Kit

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"122vh","text":"Design primers surrounding your site of interest","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1t6un","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1iq0h","text":"Optimal amplicon size 200bp","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":22,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"un1j","text":"As far as possible, the site of interest should be in the middle of the designed amplicon. (This is so that it has the best chance of being read by both the forward and reverse reads)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3ug8d","text":"If possible, try and avoid designing primers in non-coding regions of DNA since these regions are more likely to have variation and SNPs, which might affect the efficacy of your primer.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ffegj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"11qns","text":"I usually use the NCBI Primer-Blast tool. Enter ~300bp of DNA sequence around your region of interest under 'PCR Template' and set the 'Range' for the forward and reverse primer so that your site of interest is more or less in the middle of the PCR product.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":259}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":18,"length":17}],"data":[]},{"key":"6e0fs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bjkkl","text":"If you previously used a set of primers to check your TALLEN/CRISPR efficiency using Melt Curve Analysis, or if you have your primer sequence from CHOPCHOP,  you can use the same sequence to design the primers for MiSeq. Anecdotally this seems to work well for most people on their first try.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":147,"length":8}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0CFB8630B90C11EDA9B7232CB5086F6C","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/primer-blast/"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"12CE5530B91411EDA9B7232CB5086F6C","url":"https://chopchop.cbu.uib.no/"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"90bgn","text":"Add miseq tags/overhangs to your primer sequence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fnm83","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2i5gl","text":"Universal forward (F) tag: 5' TCGTCGGCAGCGTCAGATGTGTATAAGAGACAG 3'","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":30,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"730hq","text":"Universal reverse (R) tag: 5' GTCTCGTGGGCTCGGAGATGTGTATAAGAGACAG 3'","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":30,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"17mtp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3m8u3","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"etihq","text":"These overhang sequences correspond to the Illumina nextera transposase overhangs and will be compatible with Illumina kits using Nextera XT","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":140}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B5D098D0B91211EDA9B7232CB5086F6C","height":251,"id":350077,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","original_name":"Screenshot 2023-03-02 at 15.55.48.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/kx59bgqif.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/kx57bgqif.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/kx58bgqif.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/kx56bgqif.webp","width":550}}}}

your test run, you should use a gradient PCR to test the ideal temperature for your primers (Note. By default, CHOPCHOP designs primers for an optimal melting temperature of 60°C). We usually run a gradient PCR for five different temperatures, with 60°C being optimal, then varying 1°C-1.5°C above and below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"822pb","text":"Testing your primers is optional. Note! You can only submit up to 96 samples per amplicon on one MiSeq run. During the miseq process, all samples are pooled into one plate; you will only be able to distinguish between samples from the same well in different plates if their amplicons are in a different region of the genome (Basically don’t do Fish1_Guide1 in Plate 1 well B2 \u0026 Fish2_Guide1 in Plate 2 well B2 because they will be indistinguishable).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3ph0d","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":70}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":15,"offset":34,"style":"bold"}],"key":"b0c97","text":"We recommend using a high-fidelity Taq polymerase. {"blocks":[{"key":"34n4r","text":"Run on a 1% gel to confirm a single band at the anticipated weight. This is just to check the PCR worked. {"blocks":[{"key":"e8i86","text":"Prepare your samples for miseq:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5a6f9","text":"You need to submit a minimum of   at a final concentration of 15-25 ng/μL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":34,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":32,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"6tokh","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"erv6q","text":"Label your plate/tubes with your name, the date and 'For Miseq' and leave the samples with the Payne lab in the Cancer Insititute or in the Fish Facility B03 fridge in the anatomy building, whichever is most convenient for you. Once you have dropped off your samples, email Alexandra Lubin, letting her know. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":53,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":95,"length":93}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9sani","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8n5hh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bbbqh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"60qpr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"6","error":false,"guid":"B8669D00BC3311ED95D54BDB9A9F4C73","id":"93500","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"tex_formula","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"formula":"","guid":"C158A700BC3311ED95D54BDB9A9F4C73","id":0}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":45,"style":"bold"},{"length":11,"offset":71,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1aqck","text":"You could save time and plastic by combining clean-up with dilution to 15-25 ng/μL. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d8hov","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"jlig","text":"Step 1: Measure the concentration of the PCR product before clean-up","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fe7sa","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":271},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":291}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6mi70","text":"Step 2: In a new plate/tubes, add your PCR product, ExoSAP and nuclease-free water (if necessary). Volumes will differ according to the concentration of your samples. Calculate how much you need to dilute your PCR product according to the concentration you measured. Add    ExoSAP for every   you add of your PCR product and top up with nuclease-free water where needed.
